content.description: Balance up on a small crimp, and reach to a hidden jug dish (or try jumping...). Get your feet on, and top it out.
content.location: This is on the north side of the first boulder on your left when you arrive at the summit boulders. A short slab hides a great hold above.

content.description:
This is the downclimb for

Try Jumping

. It's a great friction slab for teaching your hiking friends some footwork along the way.
content.location:
It is on the backside (west) face of

Try Jumping

.

content.description: This is on a perfect, splitter boulder and is a reason to come here. Climb out of the offwidth pod into hand jams in the steep crack above.
content.protection: We rigged this for a TR solo, but this would be a fantastic highball. You could also plug some hand-size pieces if you wanted to lead it; however, there are no known anchors, and the only downclimb looks pretty hairy.
content.location:
Head west just downhill from

Try Jumping

.

content.description:
Sit at the lowest possible west end of the boulder. Pull onto crystals on the lip, and heelhook your way into finishing on

Try Jumping

.
content.location:
It is on the right(west) end of the north side of the

Try Jumping

Boulder.

content.description: SDS with a high right pinch on the arÃªte and a low left hand sidepull crimp on the face. Make a big move to the jug ledge above, and top out. Some other easy warm-ups also exist on this boulder.
content.location: Do not follow the directions listed on the main page, instead, hike to and up the Buckhorn Cutoff Trail. When the Buckhorn trail first crosses over some boulders, go off trail and uphill about 5 minutes to locate this little block (if my memory is correct). The arete is on the uphill side (NW corner). The east slab is easy. You can also climb the face right of the arete from a crouched stand start using the arete and face holds (Spike Slab V2).
